template.name: Template epmmm Linux Disk Performance
template.description: need python version 3+ need sysstat-9.0.4-33.el6_9.1.x86_64 + yum update sysstat pip3 install argparse pip3 install py-zabbix /etc/init.d/zabbix-agentd restart systemctl restart zabbix-agentd

item_prototype.name: Disk:$1:IO:Currently Active
item_prototype.description: Field #12 Number of I/Os currently in progress. The only field that should go to zero. Incremented as requests are given to appropriate struct request_queue and decremented as they finish.

item_prototype.name: Disk:$1:IO:ms
item_prototype.description: Field #13 Number of milliseconds spent doing I/Os. This field increases so long as field #12 (custom.vfs.dev.io.active) is nonzero.

item_prototype.name: Disk:$1:Read:Merged
item_prototype.description: Field #5 Number of reads merged. Reads and writes which are adjacent to each other may be merged for efficiency. Thus two 4K reads may become one 8K read before it is ultimately handed to the disk, and so it will be counted (and queued) as only one I/O. This field lets you know how often this was done.

item_prototype.name: Disk:$1:Read:ms
item_prototype.description: Field #7 Number of milliseconds spent reading This is the total number of milliseconds spent by all reads (as measured from __make_request() to end_that_request_last()).

item_prototype.name: Disk:$1:Read:Ops per second
item_prototype.description: Field #4 This is the total number of reads completed successfully.

item_prototype.name: Disk:$1:Read:Bytes/sec
item_prototype.description: Field #6 This is the total number of sectors read successfully.

item_prototype.name: Disk:$1:IO:Weight:ms
item_prototype.description: Field #14 Weighted number of milliseconds spent doing I/Os. This field is incremented at each I/O start, I/O completion, I/O merge, or read of these stats by the number of I/Os in progress (field 12) times the number of milliseconds spent doing I/O since the last update of this field. This can provide an easy measure of both I/O completion time and the backlog that may be accumulating.

item_prototype.name: Disk:$1:Write:Merged
item_prototype.description: Field #9 Number of writes merged. Reads and writes which are adjacent to each other may be merged for efficiency. Thus two 4K reads may become one 8K read before it is ultimately handed to the disk, and so it will be counted (and queued) as only one I/O. This field lets you know how often this was done.

item_prototype.name: Disk:$1:Write:ms
item_prototype.description: Field #11 Number of milliseconds spent writing. This is the total number of milliseconds spent by all writes (as measured from __make_request() to end_that_request_last()).

item_prototype.name: Disk:$1:Write:Ops per second
item_prototype.description: Field #8 This is the total number of writes completed successfully.

item_prototype.name: Disk:$1:Write:Bytes/sec
item_prototype.description: Field #10 This is the total number of sectors written successfully.

trigger.name: epmmm MaaS Agent is not sending data
trigger.description: epmmm MaaS Agent did not send any data during the last 5 minutes. This can be due to troubles with the network or because it was not running. Please check in the log file for more information.

trigger.name: MySQL is down
trigger.description: MySQL database is down. This requires immediate action!

trigger.name: MySQL is up again
trigger.description: MySQL database is up again. Please investigate why it was down before...

trigger.name: Character Set of Server is not utf8
trigger.description: The Character Set of your Server is utf8. This has performance impacts.

trigger.name: epmmm Agent is down
trigger.description: epmmm Agent was not reachable. We assume it is down!

trigger.name: Default Storage Engine is not InnoDB
trigger.description: Your Default Storage Engine is not set to InnoDB.

trigger.name: General Log is enabled
trigger.description: Your General Log is enabled. If this is a production Server under high load, this is not recommended.

trigger.name: InnoDB Plugin is enabled
trigger.description: InnoDB Plugin is enabled

item.name: InnoDB Buffer Pool Pages Data byte
InnoDB Buffer Pool Pages Dirty byte

trigger.name: InnoDB Buffer Pool Instances is too small
trigger.description: If you are using MySQL 5.5 and higher you should use several InnoDB Buffer Pool Instances for performance reasons. Some rules are: InnoDB Buffer Pool Instance should be at least 1 Gbyte in size. InnoDB Buffer Pool Instances you can set equal to the number of cores of your machine.

item.name: InnoDB Buffer Pool max dirty Pages
InnoDB Buffer Pool max dirty Pages
InnoDB Buffer Pool Pages Free byte
InnoDB Buffer Pool Pages Misc byte
InnoDB Buffer Pool Pages Total byte
InnoDB Buffer Pool read ahead evicte
InnoDB Flush Log at Transaction Commit

trigger.name: InnoDB Flush Log at Transaction Commit
trigger.description: InnoDB Flush Log at Transaction Commit is set to a values != 1. This can lead to a loss of commited transactions in case of a power failure.

trigger.name: InnoDB Flush Method has changed
trigger.description: The InnoDB Flush Method has changed. This can have an impact on InnoDB write Performance.

trigger.name: InnoDB Force Recovery is enabled
trigger.description: InnoDB Force Recovery is enabled. This mode should be used for data recovery purposes only. It prohibits writing to the data.

trigger.name: InnoDB Log File size is too small
trigger.description: The InnoDB Log File size is possibly too small. Choosing a small InnoDB Log File size can have significant performance impacts.

item.name: InnoDB Status Log Flushed up to
InnoDB Status Open Read Views inside InnoDB Core
InnoDB Status Pages Flushed up to
InnoDB Status Queries Inside InnoDB Core

trigger.name: Log Output is other than File
trigger.description: Your Log Output is not File. It can lead to problems when you run to Table for too long time.

trigger.name: Log Queries not using Indexes is disabled
trigger.description: You have not enabled log_queries_not_using_indexes. This could help you finding slow queries.

trigger.name: Slave is NOT read only
trigger.description: Slave is NOT set to read only. You can accidentally manipulate data on the slave and get inconsistencies...

trigger.name: Slave lagging behind Master
trigger.description: Slave is lagging behind Master. Please check if Slave threads are running and if there are some performance issues! But only while we do not backup... Do not check from 04:00 - 12:00

trigger.name: Slave IO thread stopped
trigger.description: IO thread has stopped. This is usually because it cannot connect to the Master any more.

item.name: slave Replay lag binlog file number

trigger.name: Slave errors are skipped
trigger.description: Slave errors are skipped! This leads to data inconsistency!

trigger.name: Thread stack size is possibly too small
trigger.description: Thread stack size is possibly too small. This can cause problems when you use Stored Language constructs for example. A typical is 256k for thread_stack_size.

trigger.name: Thread stack size is too small
trigger.description: Thread stack size is too small. This can cause problems when you use Stored Language constructs for example. A typical is 256k for thread_stack_size.

trigger.name: Transaction isolation level is set to non-recommended value
trigger.description: You transaction isolation level is set to an non-recommende value. Please consider its impacts.

template.name: Template epmmm Redis
template.description: pip3 install argparse pip3 install redis pip3 install py-zabbix

trigger.name: epmmm Agent is down
trigger.description: epmmm Agent was not reachable. We assume it is down!

template.name: Template epmmm Tendis
template.description: pip3 install argparse pip3 install redis pip3 install py-zabbix

trigger.name: epmmm Agent is down
trigger.description: epmmm Agent was not reachable. We assume it is down!

trigger.name: Tendis cluster status not ok on {HOST.NAME}

resource.name: tendis cmdstat calls info (各命令 每秒平均请求次数)
tendis cmdstat usec per call info calculated (各命令 单命令平均请求耗时,单位:微秒)
tendis rocksdb rocksdbstats l0 slowdown and stall info
tendis rocksdb rocksdbstats memtable and blockcache info

trigger.expression: {Template epmmm MySQL:epmmm.mysql.read_only.str(ON)}=1 and {Template epmmm MySQL:epmmm.mysql.MGR_status.last()}=0 and {$SERVICE_ROLE}="master"
trigger.name: async mode Master is readonly
InnoDB Log Buffer too small
trigger.description: InnoDB Log Buffer size is possible too small for the current traffic.

trigger.name: InnoDB Log File size is too small for current traffic
trigger.description: Log File Size is possibly too small for the current traffic.

trigger.expression: {Template epmmm MySQL:epmmm.mysql.read_only.str(ON)}=1 and {Template epmmm MySQL:epmmm.mysql.MGR_status.last()}=1 and {Template epmmm MySQL:epmmm.mysql.MGR_member_role.last()}=1 and {$SERVICE_ROLE}="master"
trigger.name: MGR mode PRIMARY is readonly

trigger.expression: {Template epmmm MySQL:epmmm.mysql.read_only.str(ON)}=0 and {Template epmmm MySQL:epmmm.mysql.MGR_status.last()}=1 and {Template epmmm MySQL:epmmm.mysql.MGR_member_role.last()}=0 and {$SERVICE_ROLE}="master"
trigger.name: MGR mode SECONDARY is not readonly

trigger.expression: ( {Template epmmm MySQL:epmmm.mysql.Slave_Running.last(0)}=0 and {$SERVICE_ROLE}="slave" ) or ( {Template epmmm MySQL:epmmm.mysql.Slave_Running.last(0)}=0 and {$SERVICE_ROLE}="backup" and ({Template epmmm MySQL:epmmm.mysql.Slave_IO_Running.time(0)}<={$BACKUPBEGINTIME} or {Template epmmm MySQL:epmmm.mysql.Slave_IO_Running.time(0)}>={$BACKUPENDTIME}) )
trigger.name: MySQL Slave is not running on {HOST.NAME}
Open files high
trigger.description: Open files is high. Please consider increasing open_files_limit.

trigger.name: Read buffer size is bigger than max. allowed packet size
trigger.description: Read buffer size (read_buffer_size) is bigger than max. allowed packet size (max_allowed_packet). This can break your replication.

trigger.name: Session buffer possibly missconfigured
trigger.description: Sort buffer size is either too big or too small. A good value for sort_buffer_size is between 256k and 4M.

trigger.expression: ( {Template epmmm MySQL:epmmm.mysql.Slave_SQL_Running.last(0)}=0 and {$SERVICE_ROLE}="slave" ) or ( {Template epmmm MySQL:epmmm.mysql.Slave_SQL_Running.last(0)}=0 and {$SERVICE_ROLE}="backup" and ({Template epmmm MySQL:epmmm.mysql.Slave_IO_Running.time(0)}<={$BACKUPBEGINTIME} or {Template epmmm MySQL:epmmm.mysql.Slave_IO_Running.time(0)}>={$BACKUPENDTIME}) )
trigger.name: Slave SQL thread stopped
trigger.description: SQL thread has stopped. This is usually because it cannot apply a SQL statement received from the master.

trigger.name: Table definition cache too small
trigger.description: Your Table Definition Cache is possibly too small. If it is much too small this can have significant performance impacts!

trigger.name: Table open cache too small
trigger.description: Your Table Open Cache is possibly too small (old name Table Cache). If it is much too small this can have significant performance impacts!

trigger.name: Tendis replication master link down on {HOST.NAME}
